State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China Toluene gas-phase oxidation is a green, chlorine-free production process for benzaldehyde but its conversion efficiency is still unsatisfying due to the lack of highly efficient catalyst. Here the selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde over V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 under an air atmosphere was investigated. The catalyst was prepared by impregnation and characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM), N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD), and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The amount of oxygen vacancy and acid of the catalyst can be tuned through adjusting the V:Ag:Ce ratio. Over the optimum catalyst (V:Ag:Ce = 4:2:1, molar ratio), 92% benzaldehyde selectivity with a 27% toluene conversion can be obtained at 550 °C. Medium amounts of oxygen vacancy (0.43) and acidity (0.10 mmol/g) are found to be conducive to the conversion of toluene to benzaldehyde. This study has important theoretical guiding significance for improving conversion efficiency from toluene to benzaldehyde by gas-phase aerobic oxidation. Graphical abstract A new catalyst consisting of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 with excellent catalytic performance for the oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde was developed. The selectivity reached 92% at conversion of 27% for this reaction. Such an excellent performance can be attributed to the moderate oxygen vacancy content and medium acidic sites of the catalyst. ga1 Keywords Acidity Benzaldehyde Gas-phase oxidation Heterogeneous catalysis Toluene Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Benzaldehyde is an important intermediate for medicine, dyes, herbicides, plant growth regulators, and essence. It has the characteristics of large demand, high economic benefits, and good market prospects. At present, there are many preparation methods for benzaldehyde, including toluene chlorination [1], benzyl alcohol oxidation [2,3], benzoic acid reduction [4], indirect electro-oxidation [5], toluene liquid phase oxidation [6–8] and toluene gas phase oxidation [9]. Though great progress has been made in toluene liquid phase oxidation by Pappo's group with homogeneous catalyst cobalt acetate/N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) [10,11], where a yield of > 95% for benzaldehyde was realized, the difficulty in the separation and recovery hinders its industrial production. Shi’s group reported the co-immobilization of NHPI and Co ions as a recyclable catalyst but sacrificing some activity and selectivity [12–14]. Besides, liquid phase oxidation can only be carried out in batches. On the contrary, toluene gas phase oxidation has the advantages of being easy for continuous automatic production, simple process, low cost, and easy availability. It is a green and chlorine-free production process for benzaldehyde, and has a very good application prospect. But the efficiency of gas phase oxidation must be markedly enhanced before the practical industrial application. The catalysts for gas phase oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde are mainly based on V [15–17]. At present, the benzaldehyde yield of the gas-phase toluene oxidation with V-based catalyst is only about 20%, where there is still a great need for improvement. However, it remains a great challenge to develop more advanced catalysts to further improve the yield of benzaldehyde. The main problem is the conversion–selectivity trade-off relationship. For example, only 70% selectivity can be obtained when the conversion is about 20% [18] and when the selectivity rises to 95%, the conversion simultaneously falls to 7% [19]. Thus, controlling the balance between activity and selectivity to achieve the highest yield has always been a big challenge. According to the literature study, oxygen vacancy is the active site for the oxidation of toluene [20], while the acidity is the key to control the selectivity [21], decreasing the surface acidity would lead to increased selectivity to benzaldehyde [19]. Thus, combining oxygen vacancy and suitable surface acidity is a promising strategy to achieve high activity and selectivity simultaneously. V can be selected as the basic component [15–17]. Ce helps to increase the oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface [22] which can be used to activate the conversion of gaseous oxygen to lattice oxygen to participate in the reaction and improve the conversion of toluene [23]. Metals whose oxides are alkaline, such as Cu, Mn, Mg, and Ag [19,24–27], can reduce the acidity of the catalyst surface and improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde. Both oxygen vacancy and acid site are the key active sites for catalyzing the oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde, and both of them can be tuned by regulating the molar ratio between the elements in the catalyst. The support can be screened among Al2O3-ZrO2, TiO2, and SiO2 [15,17,28]. In this paper, V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts were evolved and different V:Ag:Ce ratios were tested for the reaction of toluene gas phase oxidation to benzaldehyde. The amount of oxygen vacancy and acidity were optimized to achieve the optimum balance of activity and selectivity. A conversion up to 27% was achieved even when the benzaldehyde selectivity was as high as 92% over the optimum catalyst (V:Ag:Ce = 4:2:1). To the best of our knowledge, catalysts composed of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 have not been reported yet for toluene oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials C2H5OH, NH4VO3, AgNO3, Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, and HCl were of analytical grade and purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Company Limited). Oxalic acid, Ti(OC4H9)4, CH3COOH, C2H5OOCCH3, C6H5CH3, C6H5CHO, and C6H5C2H5 were of analytical grade and purchased from Aladdin Co., Ltd. All chemicals were directly used without further purification. The water used in the experiment was deionized water. 2.2 Preparation of TiO2 TiO2 was prepared with butyl titanate Ti(OC4H9)4 as a precursor, absolute ethanol (C2H5OH) as a solvent, and glacial acetic acid (CH3COOH) as a chelating agent. At room temperature, 10 mL of butyl titanate was slowly dropped into 35 mL of anhydrous ethanol, and a well-mixed yellow solution A was formed after 10 min of vigorous stirring with a magnetic stirrer. 4 mL of glacial acetic acid and 10 mL of distilled water were added to 35 mL of anhydrous ethanol, and solution B was obtained by vigorous stirring. 1–2 drops of hydrochloric acid were added, and the pH was adjusted to pH≤ 3. Solution A was slowly dropped into solution B in a water bath at room temperature. After dropping, a straw-colored solution was obtained. After continuous stirring for 0.5 h, it was heated in a 40 °C water bath. After 2 h, a white gel was obtained. The gel was dried at 80 °C for 20 h to obtain a yellow crystal. After grinding, a straw-yellow powder was obtained. To produce white TiO2 powder, the straw-colored powder was calcined at 500 °C for 5 h at a heating rate of 2 °C/min. 2.3 Preparation of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst NH4VO3, anhydrous oxalic acid, silver nitrate, and cerium nitrate hexahydrate were dissolved in distilled water, and their addition amounts were changed to prepare V-Ag-Ce precursor solutions with different proportions. 2 g of TiO2 powder were placed in the precursor solution, which was stirred at 80 °C for 5 h in a magnetic agitator. The obtained solid-liquid mixture was centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 10 min, then dried at 100 °C for 10 h and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h to obtain V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce ratios. In this paper, four catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce molar ratios were prepared: V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 (V:Ag:Ce=4:1:1), V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 (V:Ag:Ce=4:1:2), V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 (V:Ag:Ce=4:2:1), and V-Ag-Ce /TiO2 (V:Ag:Ce=2:1:1), and marked as C-1, C-2, C-3, and C-4, respectively. 2.4 Gas phase oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde The process of applying the metal oxide catalyst prepared by the above method to the gas-phase oxidation reaction of toluene is as follows: 0.5 g of catalyst was placed in the reaction tube; quartz sand and quartz wool were used to fix the catalyst. The reaction tube was connected to the reactor. During the experiment, different reaction results were acquired by adjusting the flow rates of air, toluene feed, and reaction temperature. The high-temperature gas flowing down from the reaction was converted into a liquid by distilled water in the condenser, and benzaldehyde was separated by extracting this liquid with water as the solvent. The product was detected by gas chromatography with ethyl benzene as an internal standard and ethyl acetate as a solvent. 2.5 Characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was tested on Nova Nano SEM 450 produced by FEI Company. X-ray diffraction (XRD-7000S, Shimadzu, Japan) was done with a Cu Kα radiation in the range of 20–80º (2θ), 2º/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected by an ESCALAB™ 250Xi (Thermo Fisher, USA) electron spectrometer using Al-Kα radiations. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) were performed by Chemstar TPx, which was produced by Quantachrome in USA. The textural information was gained from N2 sorption by an automatic physical adsorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, Autosorb-iQ-C) at 77 K. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was measured using a Bruker model A200–9.5/12 paramagnetic resonance spectrometer. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) were carried out using a Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorption instrument. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The evolvement of the catalyst composition The elements of the catalyst were elaborately screened according to the literature. V was selected as the basic component. Then the second element was chosen among Cu, Mn, Mg, and Ag. As shown in Fig. S1, Ag was the best. Then the optimum support was determined among Al2O3-ZrO2, TiO2, and SiO2. As shown in Table S1, TiO2 was better than Al2O3-ZrO2 and SiO2. Finally, the catalyst composition was determined to be V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 (Fig. S2). To our knowledge, catalysts of such composition have not been reported yet for toluene oxidation. 3.2 Catalyst characterization Firstly, SEM was used to analyze the morphologies of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce ratios. As shown in Fig. S3, the catalysts have no regular morphologies, and there is no significant difference in the morphologies of catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce ratios. The specific surface area and pore structure of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce ratios were obtained by N2 sorption-desorption analysis and shown in Table S2. The average pore size and pore volume of these catalysts showed no significant difference. It is worth noting that C-3 has the highest specific surface area, and the active component may be more evenly dispersed on the support. In order to explore the phase structure of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts, X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out (V/TiO2 and V-Ag/TiO2 for comparison). The results are shown in Fig. 1. As can be seen, for V/TiO2, no signals other than those of TiO2 can be detected, indicating that the substances formed by V were evenly dispersed on the support. When Ag was introduced to V/TiO2, the peaks of V-Ag/TiO2 did not change much, but at 2θ= 32.1°, there was a wider peak corresponding to AgVO3 (PDF#89–4396) which should be formed by the interaction of Ag and V. When Ce was introduced to V-Ag/TiO2, a sharp peak appeared at 2θ= 32.5°, corresponding to CeVO4 (PDF#84–1457). The XRD patterns of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce ratios showed no significant difference. Next, XPS was used to measure the content of oxygen vacancies in V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalysts with different V:Ag:Ce ratios, as shown in Fig. 2a and Fig. S4. The O 1 s spectrum can be generally divided into three peaks, namely physical adsorbed oxygen (Oα), chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ), and lattice oxygen (Oγ) [29], among which chemisorbed oxygen is commonly referred to oxygen vacancies [22]. The proportion of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface can be obtained through XPS analysis. The presence of oxygen vacancies were further confirmed by EPR spectroscopy (Fig. 2b). The signal at g= 2.003 suggests the presence of unpaired free single electrons that can activate gaseous O2 molecules, i.e., oxygen vacancy [30]. As can be seen, the introduction of Ce greatly increases the amount of oxygen vacancies. The peak positions of three different types of oxygen and the proportion of oxygen vacancies are statistically calculated and shown in Table 1. It can be seen from Table 1 that the content of oxygen vacancy increases greatly after Ce element was introduced into V-Ag/TiO2 catalyst, and the oxygen vacancy content of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst with different V:Ag:Ce ratios was different. The increase of oxygen vacancy is very important for catalyzing oxidation reaction since oxygen vacancy can activate the gaseous oxygen [20]. Besides, V4+, V5+, Ce3+, Ce4+ and Ag+ coexist in the catalyst according to XPS of V 2p, Ce 3d, and Ag 3d spectra (Fig. S5). Lattice oxygen activation is another factor to improve the oxidation activity [31], especially when Ag and Ce are involved [32,33]. But according to the H2-TPR and O2-TPD ( Fig. 3), the surface lattice oxygen mobility was not improved after introducing Ag and Ce. As shown in H2-TPR (Fig. 3a), the reduction temperature of VOx is not decreased after adding Ag, indicating that Ag cannot accelerate the reduction of VOx. In O2-TPD (Fig. 3b), two major resolved peaks appeared around 100 °C and 505 °C correspond to adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen, respectively [33,34]. The lattice oxygen desorption temperature is not decreased, indicating that Ce cannot enhance the lattice oxygen mobility, which is in agreement with the results of H2-TPR. It is worth noting that the peak of adsorbed oxygen (originated from the oxygen vacancies [35]) is obviously increased, indicating the great increase of oxygen vacancies after adding Ce, further supporting the results of XPS and EPR. Next, NH3-TPD was used to determine the acid sites on the surface of the catalyst and the results are shown in Fig. 4. In the NH3-TPD spectrum, it is generally considered that the peaks < 200 °C, 200 °C∼400 °C, and > 400 °C represent weak acid site, medium acid site, and strong acid site respectively [36]. The NH3-TPD spectrum of each catalyst in Fig. 4 was divided into three parts: weak acid, medium acid, and strong acid, and each part was fitted by integral fitting (Fig. S6). The results are shown in Table 2. It is obvious that the acidity of the catalyst is greatly reduced after the addition of silver. The effect of acidity on catalytic performance will be discussed later. Reaction Condition: The air flow rate at 150 mL/min, toluene flow rate at 0.35 mL/min, and reaction temperature at 500 °C. C T: toluene conversion; S B: benzaldehyde selectivity; Y B: benzaldehyde yield. 3.3 Catalytic reaction results The prepared TiO2, V/TiO2, V-Ag/TiO2 and V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst with different V:Ag:Ce ratios were used in the gas phase oxidation of toluene, and the reaction results are shown in Table 3. As can be seen from Table 3, C-3 showed the best catalytic performance. When the reaction temperature was 500 °C, the air flow rate was 150 mL/min and the toluene flow rate was 0.35 mL/min, the corresponding toluene conversion was 22%, benzaldehyde selectivity was 94%, and benzaldehyde yield was 21%. Then the effect of reaction temperature on toluene conversion was explored, as shown in Fig. 5. It can be seen that with the increase of reaction temperature, the conversion of toluene gradually increases and becomes stable after 525 °C, while the selectivity of benzaldehyde first increases and then decreases with the increase of temperature. The reason may be that the increase in reaction temperature is more conducive to the side reaction, that is, deep oxidation. When the reaction temperature was 525 °C, the highest yield of benzaldehyde was obtained, which was 25%, the corresponding toluene conversion was 27%, and the selectivity of benzaldehyde was 92%. It is worth noting that such a yield is among the best of the V-based catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6. The detailed information for Fig. 6 is provided in Table S3. 3.4 Effect of catalyst acidity on reaction Fig. 7 shows the effect of catalyst total acid amount on benzaldehyde selectivity. It can be seen that the selectivity of benzaldehyde exhibits a volcano-shaped dependence on the total acid content of catalyst. That is to say, it is more conducive to the conversion of toluene to benzaldehyde when the acid amount is medium. In order to find which acidic sites with different strengths are more favorable for the reaction, the relationship between the amount of different acidic sites and toluene conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity was explored. Fig. S7 shows the effect of the amount of different acidic sites on benzaldehyde selectivity. It can be seen that benzaldehyde selectivity are roughly distributed in a volcanic curve with the amount of medium acid. The amount of weak acid is too small, while the strong acid did not make a big difference. It can be concluded that the acid sites play an important role on the selectivity of the gas-phase oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. When the total acid content on the catalyst surface is medium, it is more conducive to the conversion of toluene and the formation of benzaldehyde. Of all three acidic sites, medium acid appeared to play a major role. Theoretically, toluene participates in the reaction by being adsorbed to the acid sites on the catalyst surface [37], but if the acidity is too strong, benzaldehyde may unable to easily get off the catalyst surface and deep oxidation may occur [38]. 3.5 Reaction mechanism Fig. 8 shows the possible reaction mechanism of preparing benzaldehyde by gas phase oxidation of toluene on V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst. There are oxygen vacancies and acid sites on the surface of the catalyst. During the reaction, toluene is first adsorbed to the acidic sites [39]. At the same time, the oxygen vacancies activate the gaseous oxygen in the air into lattice oxygen. The lattice oxygen O2 - attacks the C on toluene methyl, transferring electrons from lattice oxygen to methyl C, and O2 - is converted into O-, and then the electrons of C-H bond are transferred to H, then the C-H bond is broken, O- is bonded with methyl C, and the lattice oxygen is transformed into oxygen vacancies again. In the next step, O- continues to transfer electrons to methyl C, the electrons on C-H bond continue to transfer to H, and the other C-H bond breaks to form CO bond [40,41]. The removed H in these two steps is adsorbed to the catalyst surface, and finally the by-product water is removed. The final product benzaldehyde is desorbed from the acid sites on the catalyst surface, and the empty acid sites can adsorb toluene again [42]. Interestingly, though both oxygen vacancy and acid site are indispensable in the catalytic process, their content is not proportional to the activity. As shown before, the content of oxygen vacancy and acid of the best catalyst (C-3) are not the most among all the catalyst examined. Because both excessive activity and too strong adsorption may lead to the continued oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid or even CO2, thus not conducive to the formation of benzaldehyde. Interestingly, this is just in line with the Confucian doctrine of the mean, that is, moderation in all things is the optimal path [43]. 4 Conclusion In this paper, a series of catalysts were prepared by changing the proportion of elements V, Ag and Ce in V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Through a series of characterization, it was found that the oxygen vacancy and acid site in the catalyst played a very important role in this reaction. The oxygen vacancy was responsible for activating gaseous oxygen to lattice oxygen to participate in oxidation, and the acid site was responsible for adsorbing toluene and desorbing benzaldehyde to make the reaction proceed smoothly. Medium amount of oxygen vacancy and medium acid sites are more conducive to the conversion of toluene to benzaldehyde. coredata.dc:description: Toluene gas-phase oxidation is a green, chlorine-free production process for benzaldehyde but its conversion efficiency is still unsatisfying due to the lack of highly efficient catalyst. Here the selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde over V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 under an air atmosphere was investigated. The catalyst was prepared by impregnation and characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM), N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD), and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The amount of oxygen vacancy and acid of the catalyst can be tuned through adjusting the V:Ag:Ce ratio. Over the optimum catalyst (V:Ag:Ce = 4:2:1, molar ratio), 92% benzaldehyde selectivity with a 27% toluene conversion can be obtained at 550 °C. Medium amounts of oxygen vacancy (0.43) and acidity (0.10 mmol/g) are found to be conducive to the conversion of toluene to benzaldehyde. This study has important theoretical guiding significance for improving conversion efficiency from toluene to benzaldehyde by gas-phase aerobic oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Tuning the oxygen vacancy and acidity of V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst for selective gas-phase oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde
